questions.text: Best study of first choice for assessment of unknown/new disease with no etiological hypothesis is
questions.solution:
• Descriptive epidemiology aims to describe the distribution of disease and determinants.
  • It provides a way of organising and analysing the data to describe the variations in disease freaquency.

questions.text: Rabies is a 100% fatal disease is an expression of which of the following
questions.solution:
• in epidemiology case fatality rate is the proportion of people diagnosed with a certain disease, who end up dying of it
  • case fatality rate does not take into account the time period between disease onset and death

choices.text: Acute renal failure and Diabetic nephropathy

questions.text: 75 year old lady Geetha had Type 2 DM since 1979. She developed diabetic nephropathy in 2004 which finally resulted in acute renal failure on September 1 2014. She developed cardiorespiratory arrest and died on 7 September 2014. She also had a BMI of 32. Her cause of death and significant condition are respectively
questions.solution:
• The main underlying cause of the above patient is the development of type 2 diabetes mellitus which might have lead to microvascular and macrovascular complications.
  • it is also mentioned that BMI is 32.which points towards obesity
  • so according to the above, mentioned history the main cause of death is type 2 dm and the significant contributing to her death is obesity.

choices.text: Verification of diagnosis -> confirmation of existence of an epidemic -> defining population at risk -> rapid search for all cases and their characteristic
Defining population at risk -> rapid search for all cases and their characteristic -> verification of diagnosis -> confirmation of existence of an epidemic
Defining population at risk -> rapid search for all cases and their characteristic -> confirmation of existence of an epidemic -> verification of diagnosis

questions.text: Select the appropriate order in carrying out epidemic investigation
questions.solution:
Steps of an outbreak investigation (the correct order of the above mentioned options)

  1. verification of diagnosis
  2. confirmation of existence of an epidemic
  3. defining of population at risk
  4. rapid search for all cases and their characteristic

questions.text: Human Developmental Index is measured by all except
questions.solution:
The three parameters of human development index are

  1. life expectancy at birth
  2. literacy
  3. percapita income

questions.text: Continuous scrutiny of factors that determine the occurrence and distribution of disease and other conditions of ill-health is the definition of
questions.solution:
Surveillance is defined as the continuous scrutiny of factors that determine the occurrence and distribution of disease and other conditions of ill health

Monitoting is ongoing efforts directed at assessing the health and disease status of population.

questions.text: A person wants to study a disease X and fat consumption. He collected data for a number of people affected with X from the government hospital and details of fat consumption from food industry. This type of study is known as
questions.solution: An ecological study is an observational study defined by the level at which data are analysed, namely at the population or group level, rather than individual level. Ecological studies are often used to measure prevalence and incidence of disease, particularly when disease is rare.

questions.text: In assessing the validity of screening test, those subjects who test positive with the screening test but test negative by the gold standard test are called
questions.solution:
A test result that indicates that a person has a specific disease or condition when the person actually does not have the disease.

Some examples of false positives: A pregnancy test is positive, when in fact you aren't pregnant. A cancer screening test comes back positive, but you don't have the disease. A prenatal test comes back positive for Down's Syndrome, when your fetus does not have the disorderase or condition .

choices.text: Eliminates the problem of a possible order effect
Must take into account the problem of possible residual effects of first therapy
Eliminates the need for monitoring compliance and noncompliance

questions.text: In a randomized trial, a planned cross over design
questions.solution: Crossover trials allow the response of a subject to treatment A to be contrasted with the same subject's response to treatment B. Removing patient variation in this way makes crossover trials potentially more efficient than similar sized, parallel group trials in which each subject is exposed to only one treatment

questions.text: A diagnostic test for a particular disease has a sensitivity of 0.90 and specificity of 0.90. A single test is applied to each subject in the population in which the diseased population is 10%. What is the probability that a person positive to this test has the disease?
questions.solution: SO THE CLACULATED PPV FOR THE ABOVE CASE FROM SENSITIVITY, SPECIFICITY AND PREVELANCE IS 50%

choices.text: The tests characteristics have not changed

questions.text: Due to an effective prevention program, the prevalence of an infectious disease in a community has been reduced by 90%. A physician continues to use the same diagnostic test for the disease that she has always used. How have the tests characteristics changes?
questions.solution: As prevalence decreases, the NPV increases because there will be more true negatives for every false negative. This is because a false negative would mean that a person actually has the disease, which is unlikely because the disease is rare (low prevalence).

questions.text: The time period between the point at which disease can be detected by screening to the point at which disease would have been diagnosed with diagnostic procedure
questions.solution:
Lead time is duration of time between detection of a disease (by screening or based on a new experimental criteria) and its usual clinical presentation and diagnosis (based on traditional criteria).

LEAD TIME is advantage gained by screeing for the disease in apparently normal population.

choices.text: Net sensitivity is increased and Net specificity is decreased
Net sensitivity is decreased and Net specificity is increased
Net sensitivity remains the same and Net specificity is increased

questions.text: A Haemoccult test with sensitivity of 70% and specificity of 75% is applied for detecting Colon cancer. If Haemoccult test is negative, no further testing is done. If test is positive the individual will have a second sample tested with Haemoccult II test. If second sample also tests positive for blood, they will be referred for more extensive evaluation. The effect on net sensitivity and specificity of this method of screening is
questions.solution:
• two screening tests are used in series
  • a population is subjected to one screening test followed by a second screening test.
  • second screening test is applied on those individulas only who test positive on the 1st screening test.so automatically overall sensitivity will decrease
  • sensitivity is inversely related to specificity, so overall specificity will increase

choices.text: INH prophylaxis to a baby born to mother with TB

questions.text: Which of the following is not primary prevention
questions.solution:
• primary prevention involves health promotion and risk reduction in the general population so that invasive cancers do not develop. These primary preventive measures include the cessation of smoking, lifestyle and diet modification, vitamins and micronutrients supplementation
  • Secondary prevention, comprising diagnostic tests (e.g. mammography, ultrasonography, magnetic resonance imaging, breast self-examination, as well as modern and more precise imaging methods) help the early detection of tumours or lesions predisposing to tumours.

questions.text: Small Pox vaccine was introduced by
questions.solution:
The smallpox vaccine protects people from smallpox by helping their bodies develop immunity to smallpox. The vaccine is made from a virus called vaccinia, which is a poxvirus similar to smallpox, but less harmful.

Edward Jenner is considered the founder of vaccinology in the West in 1796, after he inoculated a 13 year-old-boy with vaccinia virus (cowpox), and demonstrated immunity to smallpox. In 1798, the first smallpox vaccine was developed.

choices.text: Age categorized as young, middle-aged or old

questions.text: Which of the following variables is an example for a nominal scale.
questions.solution:
A nominal scale is a scale of measurement used to assign events or objects into discrete categories. This form of scale does not require the use of numeric values or categories ranked by class, but simply unique identifiers to label each distinct category.

Examples:

Gender, nationality, ethnicity, language, biological species etc.

questions.text: In which of the following nonrandom sampling techniques does the researcher ask the research participants to identify other potential research participants?
questions.solution: Snowball sampling is a recruitment technique in which research participants are asked to assist researchers in identifying other potential subjects. ... If the topic is sensitive or personal, snowball sampling may be justified, but care should be taken to ensure that the potential subjects' privacy is not violated.

questions.text: Which of the following requires more than one variable?
questions.solution: The scatter diagram graphs pairs of numerical data, with one variable on each axis, to look for a relationship between them. If the variables are correlated, the points will fall along a line or curve.

questions.text: The FBS levels for a group of diabetics is found to be normally distributed with a mean of 105mg per 100ml of blood& a SD of 10mg/100ml. 95% of diabetics will have their FBS levels within the limits of
questions.solution:
MEAN=105MG/100ML

SD=10MG/100ML

95%PREDICTION INTERVAL =MEAN ±2SD

                                         =105±10

                                         =85 AND 125 MG

choices.text: The standard deviation is the square root of the variance
The variance is the square root of the standard deviation
The standard deviation is the variance divided by the square root of sample size
The variance is the standard deviation divided by the square root of sample size

questions.text: The algebraic relationship between the variance and standard deviation is that:
The interquartile range covers what proportion of a distribution?
questions.solution: The interquartile range (IQR) measures the spread of the middle half of your data. It is the range for the middle 50% of your sample. Use the IQR to assess the variability where most of your values lie. Larger values indicate that the central portion of your data spread out further.

questions.text: A cardiologist wants to study the effect of an antihypertensive drug. He notes down the initial systolic BP(mmHg) of 50 patients and then administer the drug on them. After a week's treatment, he again measures the BP. Which is the most appropriate statistical test of significance to test the change in BP.
questions.solution:
A paired t-test is used when we are interested in the difference between two variables for the same subject. Often the two variables are separated by time.

An unpaired t test is a statistical procedure that compares the averages /means of two independent or unrelated variables groups to determine if there is significant difference between two groups

questions.text: Which distribution is the weekly number of car accidents on a stretch of road likely to follow?
questions.solution: In statistics, a Poisson distribution is a probability distribution that is used to show how many times an event is likely to occur over a specified period. In other words, it is a count distribution. Poisson distributions are often used to understand independent events that occur at a constant rate within a given interval of time.

questions.text: Receiver Operator Characteristic(ROC) curve is usually drawn between
questions.solution: A ROC curve is constructed by plotting the true positive rate (TPR) against the false positive rate (FPR). The true positive rate is the proportion of observations that were correctly predicted to be positive out of all positive observations (TP/(TP + FN)).

questions.text: In a 3x4 contingency table, the number of degrees of freedom equals to
questions.solution:
Degree of freedom =(R-1)(C-1)

                            =(3-1)(4-1)

                             =6

questions.text: The discipline ergonomics refers to
questions.solution: Ergonomics is the scientific discipline concerned with the understanding of interactions among humans and other elements of a system, and the profession that applies theory, principles, data and methods to design in order to optimise human well-being and overall system performance.

questions.text: Arrange the following phases of disaster cycle in a logical sequence
questions.solution:
5 Stages of the Disaster-Management Cycle

Prevention. The best way to address a disaster is by being proactive. ...

Mitigation. Mitigation aims to minimize the loss of human life that would result from a disaster. ...

Preparedness. ...

Response. ...

Recovery.

questions.text: What is the colour coding of bag in hospitals to dispose of human anatomical wastes such as body parts
Time taken for any project is estimated by
questions.solution:
The network analysis is a method used to analyze, control and monitoring of business processes and workflows. The network analysis enables project managers to take various factors into account when creating a project plan: Dependencies between activities.

Among basic network analysis methods include: Method CPM (Critical Path Method) CCM (Critical Chain Method) PERT Method (Program Evaluation and Review Technique)

questions.text: Disinfecting action of chlorine on water is mainly due to
questions.solution:
• The disinfecting action of chlorine is mainly due to the hypochlorous acid, and to a small extent due to the hypochlorite ions.
  • The hypochlorous acid is the most effective form of chlorine for water disinfection.

questions.text: Demographic goal of NRR of 1 can be achieved if CPR exceeds
questions.solution:
Couple Protection Rate (CPR)

  • It is an indicator of the prevalence of contraceptive practice in the community
  • Definition: the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or the other approved methods of family planning.
  • FOR NRR TO BE 1, COUPLE PROTECTION RATIO SHOULD EXCEED 60%

questions.text: WHO defined adolescent age between
questions.solution:
Adolescence is the phase of life between childhood and adulthood, from ages 10 to 19.

Adolescence (from Latin adolescere 'to mature') is a transitional stage of physical and psychological development that generally occurs during the period from puberty to legal adulthood (age of majority).

Adolescence is usually associated with the teenage years, but its physical, psychological or cultural expressions may begin earlier and end later

questions.text: For a population of 10000, sex ratio of more than 1000 means
questions.solution: Total population is 10000. So, sex ratio is more than 1000, it implies, females are more than 1000 per 1000 males. Thus females are >5000, and males are <5000.

questions.text: Which of the following year in history of Indian demography is known as year of big divide?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1921.

The year 1921 is known as the year demographic divide because it is the only census year when there was a decrease in the growth of population.

After 1921, there has been a trend of continuous rise in population.

questions.text: Which of the following is 4th generation IUCD
questions.solution:
GYNEFIX IS FOURTH GENERATION IUCD

GyneFix is a very small copper-based intrauterine device (IUD) that offers over 99% effectiveness at preventing pregnancies over five years.

It is smaller than any other IUD.

The size of an IUD is closely related to the side effects it causes, so that smaller devices are better tolerated with less effect on the amount of menstrual blood loss

The small GyneFix does not increase menstrual blood. This is an advantage over conventional IUD's that can induce heavy periods.

Heavy menstrual bleeding is the most common cause for the removal of an IUD.

questions.text: Following vasectomy, a patient should be advised other methods of contraception till
questions.solution:
Keep in mind that vasectomies don't offer immediate protection against pregnancy

Sperm are stored in the vas deferens and will remain there for a few weeks or months after the procedure.

This is why doctors recommend that people use an alternative method of contraception for at least three months after the procedure.

questions.text: In a community of 5000 people, the CBR is 30 per 1000 people. Find out the number of pregnant females
questions.solution:
CRUDE BIRTH RATE IS 30 PER 1000 POPULATION, SO FOR 5000 POPULATION IT IS 150.

10PERCENT OF PREGNANCIES WASTAGE = 10% OF  150

                                                                           =15

SO TOTAL NUMBER OF EXPECTED PREGNANCIES =150+15

                                                                                   =165

questions.text: Minimum antenatal visits as per MCH is
questions.solution:
IDEAL NO. OF ANTENATAL VISITS ARE USUALLY

>ONCE EVERY MONTH FOR THE FIRS 7 MONTH

>TWICE A MONTH FOR THE NEXT TWO MONTHS

>ONCE A WEEK THERE AFTER

ATLEAST  4 VISITS ARE MINIMUM AS PER MCH

1ST VISIT -WITH IN 12 WEEKS

2ND VISIT -14-26 WEEKS

3RD VISIST – 28-34 WEEKS

4TH VISIT-36 WEES -TERM

questions.text: As compared to Cows milk, human milk has
questions.solution: AS COMPARED TO COW MILK, HUMAN MILK HAS MORE IRON

questions.text: Deficit in weight for height in a three year old child indicates
questions.solution:
Acute malnutrition is a nutritional deficiency resulting from either inadequate energy or protein intake.

Children with primary acute malnutrition are common in developing countries as a result of inadequate food supply caused by social, economic, and environmental factors.

ACUTE MALNUTRITION IS DEFINES AS LOW WEIGHT FOR HEIGHT

CHRPONIC MALNUTRITION IS LOW HEIGHT FOR AGE

questions.text: Which one of the following is not used for testing adequate pasteurization of milk
questions.solution: METHYLENE BLUE REDUCTION TEST KNOWN AS MBRT IS USED AS QUICK METHOD TO ASSES THE MICROBIOLOGICAL PROPERTY OF RAW AND PASTEURISED MILK

questions.text: In measles which vitamin deficiency occurs
questions.solution:
Since the children who are most likely to be hospitalized due to measles are often deficient in vitamin A and vitamin A deficiency is more common in disadvantaged children, providing children with vitamin A to treat their measles can help the most disadvantaged children.

Vitamin A deficiency affects the severity of measles, delays recovery, can lead to measles-related complications, including blindness, and is associated with a higher rate of death

questions.text: Endemic ascites is associated with the following
questions.solution: Endemic ascites is caused by a hepatotoxin – pyrrolizidine alkaloid found in weed seeds of Crotolaria (Jhunjhunia).

choices.text: Empowerment of females under maternity benefit scheme
Free and compulsory education for girl child

questions.text: Kishori Shakthi Yojana (KSY) is
questions.solution: Kishori Shakti Yojana is a scheme initiated by Ministry of Women and Child Development in India, implemented by the Government for juvenile girls aged 11 to 18 under the Integrated Child Development Services government programme.

questions.text: In which vector only larval stage can transmit disease
questions.solution:
Trombiculid chigger mites are a common cause of mite-induced dermatitis in brushy areas

The larval, six-legged, mite is most commonly found attached to the host. The eight-legged, nymph and adult stages are found less commonly

Only larval stage is found to transmit the disease

choices.text: Panel of 4-8 experts discuss a health topic

questions.text: All are true about panel discussion except
questions.solution:
A panel discussion, or simply a panel, involves a group of people gathered to discuss a topic in front of an audience, typically at scientific, business, or academic conferences, fan conventions, and on television shows.

PANEL COMPRISES OF 4-8 EXPERTS

THERE IS NO SPECIFIC ORDER OR SET SPEECHES IN PANEL DISCUSSION

questions.text: Cognitive learning is associated with
questions.solution: COGNITIVE LEARNING IS DEFINES AS THE ACQUISITION OF KNOWLEDGE AND SKILL BY MENTAL OR COGNITIVE PROCESS

questions.text: All of the following are pillars of primary health care except
questions.solution:
FOUR PILLARS OF PHC

  1. EUITABLE DISTRIBUTION
  2. COMMUNITY PARTICIPATION
  3. APPROPRIATE TECHNOLOGY
  4. INTERSECTORAL COORDINATION
